name: Musubi (Creative Power)
shortDescription: The creative and connecting power of the kami, the force that binds all things in relationship
fullDescription: Musubi (Áî£Èúä or Áµê„Å≥) is a fundamental concept in Shinto representing the creative, generative, and connective power of the kami. The word derives from musu (Áîü„Åô, 'to produce, generate') and bi/hi (Èúä, 'spiritual power'), literally meaning 'the spiritual power of birth and creation.' Musubi operates on multiple levels: cosmic (the creative force that brings existence from potential), biological (the power of growth and reproduction), social (the bonds between people), and spiritual (the connection between humans and kami). Two primordial deities embody this principle: Takamimusubi-no-Kami and Kamimusubi-no-Kami, who appeared at the beginning of creation. Musubi manifests in: rice balls (omusubi/onigiri), tied cords (sacred rope knots), marriage bonds (en-musubi, 'tying fate'), relationships of all kinds, the binding of agreements, and the connecting power of ritual. The concept emphasizes interconnection‚Äînothing exists in isolation, all things are bound together through musubi. In Shinto thought, musubi is the active principle of kami, the way divine power manifests in the world through growth, connection, and creation.

manifestations.description: Musubi manifests in: the primordial creation of the universe, the growth of plants and living things, the conception and birth of children, the formation of relationships (especially marriage), the bonds of community and family, the tying of sacred knots and cords, the making of omusubi (rice balls) as sustenance and connection, the binding of promises and agreements, and the connection between worshippers and kami through ritual.

firstAttestation.description: Estimated based on mythology literary tradition
